objective.answer: The primary objective of the paper is to present dZiner, an AI agent powered by large language models, for the rational inverse design of materials with desired properties. The authors aim to enable efficient discovery of new compounds by integrating domain-specific knowledge from scientific literature, surrogate models, and human feedback into an iterative design process. The framework is demonstrated across various materials design tasks, including surfactants, drug candidates, and metal-organic frameworks.
objective.evidence: In this work, we present dZiner, a chemist AI agent, powered by large language models (LLMs), that discovers new compounds with desired properties via inverse design (property-to-structure). In specific, the agent leverages domain-specific insights from foundational scientific literature to propose new materials with enhanced chemical properties, iteratively evaluating them using relevant surrogate models in a rational design process, while accounting for design constraints.

knowledge_gap.answer: There is a lack of frameworks that can efficiently integrate structured experimental data, chemical domain knowledge, and context from scientific literature into data-driven workflows for materials discovery, especially when large training datasets are unavailable or experimental budgets are limited.
knowledge_gap.evidence: Despite the wealth of existing scientific literature, the availability of both structured experimental data and chemical domain knowledge that can be easily integrated into data-driven workflows is limited. ... However, these models face challenges when such data is unavailable or when there is only a limited budget for conducting experiments or simulations. In contrast, a human expert would be much more effective in such cases, by leveraging their domain knowledge and reasoning from limited examples. This underscores the need for a new materials design paradigm, where models are built to replicate and/or integrate the expertise of human domain experts.

answer: Development of dZiner, an AI agent that performs rational inverse design of materials by integrating large language models with domain-specific knowledge retrieval and surrogate property prediction.
Support for both closed-loop and human-in-the-loop feedback cycles, enabling real-time human-AI collaboration in molecular design.
Dynamic retrieval of design guidelines from scientific literature and integration with property prediction and chemical feasibility assessment in an iterative workflow.
Application of the framework to diverse materials design tasks, including surfactants, drug candidates, and metal-organic frameworks, demonstrating flexibility and adaptability.
evidence: In this work, we present dZiner, an agent-based framework for rational inverse design of materials, powered by the state-of-the-art LLMs (Figure 1). Leveraging both human expertise and the existing knowledge contained in scientific publications, dZiner acts as an intelligent chemist research assistant [36], providing feedback on every step of the iterative inverse design process.

The model supports both closed-loop and human-in-the-loop feedback cycles enabling human-AI collaboration in molecular design with real-time property inference, and uncertainty and chemical feasibility assessment.

The agent then interprets human-provided instructions or any design constraints, along with retrieving chemical knowledge from relevant scientific literature, the Internet or other resources to identify possible chemical modifications that could potentially improve the target molecular property.
We demonstrate the flexibility of this agent by applying it to various materials target properties including surfactants, ligand and drug candidates, and metal-organic frameworks.

answer: - Qin et al. (2021) Their Graph Convolutional Neural Network for predicting critical micelle concentration is used as the surrogate model for surfactant design. (Methodological precursors)
- García-Ortegón et al. (2022) Dockstring and AutoDock Vina are used for molecular docking surrogate modeling in drug design. (Methodological precursors)
- Cao et al. (2023) MOFormer is used as the surrogate model for predicting metal-organic framework properties. (Methodological precursors)
evidence: This model is based on the work of Qin et al. [84] without any adaptations. The authors used a Graph Convolutional Neural Network (GCN) to predict the critical micelle concentration (CMC) of surfactants based on their molecular structure as SMILES input.

This model utilizes on Dockstring [85], to predict the fit and binding affinity of small molecules (ligands) bind to target proteins by using molecular docking. Dockstring is a user-friendly Python wrapper for AutoDock Vina [60].
This model is based on MOFormer, a self-supervised Transformer model developed for predicting the properties of Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs) using a structure-agnostic approach [70].

performance_summary: dZiner, powered by Claude 3.5 Sonnet, outperformed GPT-4o in generating valid molecules and optimizing target properties across all three tasks (surfactant CMC, drug docking, MOF CO2 adsorption), especially when leveraging domain-knowledge from literature.

With domain-knowledge, success rates for valid SMILES generation, property improvement, and meeting design constraints were consistently higher (e.g., 96% valid SMILES for CMC with Claude 3.5 Sonnet vs. 79% for GPT-4o).
Average improvements in primary objectives (log(CMC), docking score, CO2 adsorption) were significantly higher with domain-knowledge (e.g., 137% improvement in log(CMC) for Claude 3.5 Sonnet).
Baseline runs without domain-knowledge exhibited high failure rates in generating valid structures and optimizing properties.
baselines: Baseline: Model runs without retrieving domain-knowledge (design guidelines) from scientific literature, relying only on the stand-alone large language model.
benchmark_datasets: CMC dataset: Experimentally measured CMC values for 202 surfactants, used for training and evaluating the Graph Convolutional Neural Network surrogate model.
hMOF dataset: Contains organic linkers and MOF structures, used for training and evaluating the MOFormer surrogate model for CO2 adsorption.
WDR5 (PDB: 3UVL): Protein structure used for docking surrogate model evaluation.
evaluation_metrics: Valid SMILES Generation: Percentage of generated molecules with valid chemical structures.
Primary Objective Improvement: Percentage of molecules with improved target property (log(CMC), docking score, CO2 adsorption) compared to initial candidate.
Meeting Design Constraints: Percentage of molecules meeting molecular weight and forbidden functional group constraints.
SA Score: Synthetic accessibility score, measuring ease of synthesis.
QED Score: Quantitative estimate of drug-likeness.
Average Improvement: Improvement in primary objective for best candidate compared to initial candidate.
evidence: Tables 1 and 2 provide a detailed breakdown of dZiner’s performance across three inverse design tasks—CMC, WDR5 docking, and CO2 adsorption—evaluating its success with and without domain-knowledge (each was used to generate 600 molecules across all tasks). Across these tasks, dZiner, powered by Claude 3.5 Sonnet, outperforms GPT-4o significantly in both conditions, with especially high success rates when leveraging domain-knowledge from the literature.

Table 1: dZiner’s success rates for the three inverse design tasks with different target properties, evaluated over the generation of 100 molecules per task. Primary objectives for each task are in bold. The baselines include model runs without retrieving domain-knowledge (design guidelines) from the scientific literature.

Table 2: dZiner’s improvement rates for the primary objectives in the three inverse design tasks with different target properties, evaluated over the generation of 100 molecules per task. On average, improvements are determined by comparing the best candidate from each run to the initial candidate (iteration 0). The baselines include model runs without retrieving domain-knowledge (design guidelines) from the scientific literature.

CMC training data were experimentally measured at room temperature (between 20 and 25 ◦C) in water for 202 surfactants coming from various classes, including nonionic, cationic, anionic, and zwitterionic.
These MOFs come with pcu topology and three types of inorganic nodes: Cu paddlewheel, Zn paddlewheel, and Zn tetramer (three most frequent node-topology pairs in the hMOF dataset [69]).

WDR5 (PDB: 3UVL) [86] was accessed on May 30th 2024 and was prepared for molecular docking in MGLTools / Python Molecular Viewer (1.5.7) by removing the Histone-lysine N-methyltransferase MLL3 peptide ligand, cofactors, and water.

limitations.label: SMILES Representation Limitations
limitations.explanation: SMILES can oversimplify complex structures, especially for metal-organic frameworks, and unique SMILES codes for each substitution pattern can hinder one-to-one mapping.
limitations.evidence: For example, SMILES can be a major oversimplification, especially for complex structures like MOFs. Another limitation inherent to SMILES is that unique SMILES codes can be generated for each substitution pattern, leading to a lack of a one-to-one mapping between molecules and their SMILES representations.

limitations.label: Limited Interpretation of Chemical Terms
limitations.explanation: The model had limited success in interpreting terms like ortho, meta, and para for aromatic substitution patterns in human-in-the-loop runs.
limitations.evidence: For human-in-the-loop runs, the model had limited success in interpreting terms like ortho, meta, and para when a ring has three or more substituents. As an example, it struggled with prompts like “move the -NH2 group so it is para to the -CF3 group”.

limitations.label: Potential Loss of Performance with Alternative Representations
limitations.explanation: Using less common molecular representations (e.g., BigSMILES, SMARTS) may reduce model performance due to limited training data.
limitations.evidence: It should be noted that given that these other molecular representations are not as popular, the model may lose performance when generating valid candidates.

evidence: For example, SMILES can be a major oversimplification, especially for complex structures like MOFs. Another limitation inherent to SMILES is that unique SMILES codes can be generated for each substitution pattern, leading to a lack of a one-to-one mapping between molecules and their SMILES representations.

For human-in-the-loop runs, the model had limited success in interpreting terms like ortho, meta, and para when a ring has three or more substituents. As an example, it struggled with prompts like “move the -NH2 group so it is para to the -CF3 group”.
It should be noted that given that these other molecular representations are not as popular, the model may lose performance when generating valid candidates.

Further domain-specific fine-tuning or augmentation with additional validation tools to improve interpretation of chemical terms and rules.

evidence: The incorporation of multi-modal data (such as the ability to interpret images and schemes) from supporting literature represents a key advancement that could further improve the performance of the model. This improvement would be especially impactful for small molecule virtual screening tasks.

For example, for stochastic design tasks such as the synthesis of polymers, molecular representations like BigSMILES [71] or SMILES Arbitrary Target Specification (SMARTS) [72], which may better capture the complexity of such systems [73].

This likely a result of the zero-shot learning approach and could be resolved with further domain-specific fine-tuning. Alternatively, adding more instructive human feedbacks or augmenting the agent with additional validation tools to better incorporate chemical rules is expected to alleviate this limitation.
